document_metadata.title: Challenges in Representation Learning: A report on three machine learning contests

base_methods.evidence_text: The top-performing teams used convolutional neural networks, with the winner employing an SVM primal objective as the loss function.
Other top performers used methods such as sparse filtering, entropy regularization, and ensemble voting techniques with denoising autoencoders and maxout networks.

base_methods.method_name: ensemble voting techniques with denoising autoencoders and maxout networks
base_methods.evidence_text: Other top performers used methods such as sparse filtering, entropy regularization, and ensemble voting techniques with denoising autoencoders and maxout networks.

compared_methods.method_name: null model (convolutional network with no feature learning)
compared_methods.comparison_result: the best 'null' model achieved an accuracy of 60%
compared_methods.evidence_text: The contest utilized the Facial Expression Recognition 2013 (FER-2013) dataset... Human performance on a similar dataset was estimated at 68±5%, while the best 'null' model... achieved an accuracy of 60%.

datasets_used.dataset_description: an obfuscated subset of the Street View House Numbers dataset
datasets_used.evidence_text: The black box learning challenge had two objectives... The BBL-2013 dataset, created by Dumitru Erhan, was an obfuscated subset of the Street View House Numbers dataset.

datasets_used.dataset_description: nearly 36,000 images categorized into seven emotions
datasets_used.evidence_text: In the facial expression recognition challenge... the contest utilized the Facial Expression Recognition 2013 (FER-2013) dataset, compiled by Pierre Luc Carrier and Aaron Courville.

quantitative_results.evidence_text: David Thaler won with an accuracy of 70.22% using a blend of models.
Human performance on a similar dataset was estimated at 68±5%, while the best 'null' model... achieved an accuracy of 60%.
